Caption:
Para compreender verdadeiramente Ichinen Sanzen e a obtenção do estado de Buda, é essencial reconhecer o Buda histórico como uma manifestação do Buda Eterno. No capítulo de Expedientes, parte da explicação foi abordada, mas a plena realização do estado de Buda depende da revelação do Buda Eterno no capítulo da Duração da Vida do Tathagata. Sem isso, nossa natureza búdica não pode ser plenamente ativada.

Nichiren Shonin compara a necessidade do Buda Eterno à de um ovo necessitando de um pássaro progenitor para não apodrecer. Quando o Buda Eterno, que alcançou a iluminação no passado remoto, é revelado, compreendemos nossa conexão eterna com ele, como filhos do Buda Shakyamuni, o Buda Eterno.

Independentemente de nossas condições, o Buda Eterno nos protege com sua compaixão e sabedoria, possibilitando que nos tornemos praticantes de Hokke. Nossa existência é sustentada pelas bênçãos contínuas do Buda Eterno. Mesmo em dificuldades, devemos ser gratos pela compaixão infinita do Buda Eterno, cuja conexão conosco nunca se rompe.

O verdadeiro significado de Ichinen Sanzen, a essência do Sutra do Lótus, está na revelação do Buda Eterno. Nichiren Shonin nos orienta a considerar profundamente esse significado ao avaliar todos os sutras.

Por Reverendo Sinyou Tsuchiya

Caption:
No Budismo Theravada, a maioria das pessoas se torna monge em média em três meses, aprendendo os ensinamentos básicos do Budismo Hinayana, e praticando meditação em locais tranquilos. Você poderá controlar sua própria mente e obter paz enquanto continuar sendo um monge Theravada. No entanto, você terá que voltar ao mundo cheio de desejos mundanos novamente depois de três meses.
Você não pode escapar do sofrimento que advém de estar separado daqueles que amamos, do sofrimento que advém de estar junto com aqueles a quem odiamos, do sofrimento que advém do fato de não podermos ter o que queremos, do sofrimento que advém do fato de estarmos apegados aos cinco agregados elementares do corpo e da mente.
Você pode ter sido capaz de controlar sua própria mente enquanto está sentado em silêncio, mas é difícil controlar a mente de outras pessoas no mundo real. Você tem que ganhar a vida e lidar com situações difíceis. O Budismo Theravada, Hinayana, é importante como o básico do Budismo. Eu já aprendi e pratiquei esse budismo básico. Eu acho que você deveria aprender o Mahayana, com o Sutra do Lótus, que pode te guiar a superar as dificuldades do mundo real como um Bodhisattva, sem dizer qual é o verdadeiro Budismo ou qual é o superior. Ambos os crentes do Theravada e do Sutra do Lótus adoram o Buda Shakyamuni, Gautama, para sempre.
ㅤ
Por Reverendo Sinyou Tsuchiya

Caption:
Aqueles que praticam o Sutra do Lótus não são seres humanos comuns. Muitos deles já alcançaram uma grande compreensão e vieram a este mundo como seres humanos para propagar o Sutra do Lótus. Aqueles que estão divulgando o Sutra do Lótus já obtiveram uma grande virtude e também alcançaram um bom resultado que os permite nascer livremente em qualquer lugar. No entanto, por causa da compaixão pelas pessoas, eles abandonaram a terra pura e adiaram de se tornarem Budas, e estão propagando o Sutra do Lótus neste mundo mau, apesar de sofrerem perseguições. Assim, o praticante do Sutra do Lótus é uma pessoa realmente nobre. Portanto, é dito que você deve fazer oferendas a ele como se estivesse fazendo isso ao Buda.
ㅤ
Por Reverendo Sinyou Tsuchiya

Caption:
~
Biographies of the Seventeen Indian Buddhist Masters ~ known as the Nalanda Masters

17. Atisha (980-1054 C.E.)

Continuation

Inviting Atisha to Tibet

Although the Buddha Dharma had been brought to Tibet several centuries earlier through the efforts primarily of Guru Rinpoche Padmasambhava (Gu-ru Rin-po-che Pad-ma ‘byung-gnas) and several others, this early flowering suffered a great setback due to repression by King Langdarma (Glang-dar-ma) (863 – 906 C.E.). Few practitioners were left and afterwards many points were no longer properly understood. Many felt that the practices of ethical self-discipline and tantra were mutually exclusive and that enlightenment could be achieved through intoxication and various forms of sexual misconduct. Others believed that likewise contradictory were the teachings of Hinayana and Mahayana, leading respectively to liberation and enlightenment.

To be continued.

Download more information about the Nalanda Tradition and the seventeen Nalanda Masters: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/y4w2v4ss0toftk1/AADwe2pnp6kF-LGdavVh_8t5a?dl=0
(Folder "Dharma scriptures", subfolder "Nalanda Tradition")

The names of the seventeen Nalanda Masters are:
01. Nagarjuna (one of the Six Ornaments)
02. Aryadeva (one of the Six Ornaments)
03. Buddhapalita
04. Bhavaviveka
05. Chandrakirti
06. Shantideva
07. Shantarakshita
08. Kamalashila
09. Asanga (one of the Six Ornaments)
10. Vasubhandu (one of the Six Ornaments)
11. Dignaga (one of the Six Ornaments)
12. Dharmakirti (one of the Six Ornaments)
13. Haribhadra
14. Vimuktisena
15. Gunaprabha (one of the Two Supreme Ones)
16. Shakyaprabha (one of the Two Supreme Ones)
17. Atisha

Caption:
~
Lama Tsongkhapa - Life Story in 15 Thangkas

Chintamani Rosary Spreading the Buddha’s Teachings; Great Ocean of Benefit and Joy

A Method for Depicting the Sacred Biography of the Great Jetsun Tsongkhapa on Painted Cloth in One Hundred and Fifty-Three Parts

By Kunkhyen Jamyang Shepai Dorje

Continuation

Thangka 4:
…
(12) In autumn Tsongkhapa accepted many offerings which had been sent from his birthplace. In Maldro Lhalung, he trained his mind in tantra under the guidance of Lama Sonam Dragpa. He stayed in strict retreat and studied a commentary on pramana called Treasury of Reasonings. Upon developing an extraordinary realization, tears streamed from his eyes and his hairs continuously stood on end.

To be continued, always on Tuesdays.

Translated by Ven. Tenzin Legtsok

Caption:
~
Praise of the Twelve Acts of the Buddha
by Jigme Lingpa

Continuation
…
Through three incalculable aeons in samsaric existence,
You sought the meaningful, by binding all your thoughts
With the rope of accumulating merit and wisdom.
Then, beneath the bodhi tree, you put the māras to flight,
And attained enlightenment, as all the buddhas do.
On the ship of the three turnings of the Wheel of Dharma, you save
Beings who rush into saṃsāra’s bottomless and endless abyss,
And ferry them to the perfect levels of liberation and omniscience:
I bow to you in homage!
…
To be continued

This is the word of Rigdzin Jigme Lingpa.

Download full text: https://www.lotsawahouse.org/tibetan-masters/jigme-lingpa/praise-twelve-acts-buddha

Thanks to: Rigpa Translations

The twelve great acts of Buddha Shakyamuni are:

1. The descent from Tushita, the Joyous pure land,
2. Entering the mother’s womb,
3. Taking birth,
4. Becoming skilled in various arts,
5. Delighting in the company of royal consorts,
6. Developing renunciation and becoming ordained,
7. Practicing austerities for six years,
8. Proceeding to the foot of the Bodhi tree,
9. Overcoming Mara’s hosts ,
10. Becoming fully enlightened,
11. Turning the wheel of Dharma and
12. Passing into Mahaparinirvana.

For further elaboration and information on the twelve deeds of the Buddha, see: Encyclopedia Buddhica Fall 2019 (https://encyclopediabuddhicaf19.andrewquintman.wescreates.wesleyan.edu/blog/t/the-twelve-acts/)

Caption:
We offer a wide variety of accommodations for your personal retreat at Crestone Mountain Zen Center. 

The Edge Cabin, our newest and most spacious private cabin, sits on the edge of the forest and canyon, offering stunning views of the ancient Crestone Peaks and the expansive San Luis Valley, a landscape that was once a massive lake.

From the secluded porch of the Edge Cabin, you can take in the vast valley, forest branches, and majestic peaks. The cabin is equipped with a kitchenette, toilet, tub, shower, desk, internet, queen bed, yoga and meditation space, and cozy chairs.

Find a home, a shelter, a sanctum in this shareable vastness. Step back, step in, and step within!

To learn more about personal retreat pricing, visit our website or contact us by submitting a form from our website.

WISDOM EYES

The Eyes of Buddha is a symbol in Buddhist art representing the all-seeing eyes of the Buddha.

The Eyes of Buddha are often painted onto Tibetan stupas, and are found most commonly throughout Nepal. The symbol is typically painted onto all four sides at the top of the stupa, to symbolize the Buddha’s wisdom and ability to see all things in each of the four cardinal directions.

尼采曾經這樣說過：
「人類的生命，不能以時間長短來衡量，心中充滿愛時，剎那即永恆！真的是不能以時間長短來衡量的。」

我此刻比較被他這兩句話感動和勉勵，很有共鳴：
「一個人知道自己為什麼而活，
 就可以忍受任何一種生活。」

而以下的一段話，值得您我領悟和明白：
「千萬不要妄自菲薄，否則只會束縛自己的思想與行為。一切就從尊敬自己開始，尊敬一事無成，毫無成就的自己。只要懂得尊敬自己，就不會為非作歹，做出讓人輕蔑的行為。只要改變生活方式，便能更接近自己的理想，成為別人學習的榜樣。還能大幅拓展自己的潛力，得到達成目標的力量。唯有尊敬自己，才能活得更精采。」

感恩🙏共勉之

Caption: Partage Rimé | Plaisir à partager | Jardinement votre | Réf. n° 597 | Les charmes de cinq beautés - Les estampes pour éventails d’Hiroshige, témoins rares et précieux de l’art ukiyo-e… Les éventails plats en bambou étaient un accessoire saisonnier et éphémère populaire au Japon à l’époque d’Edo. À la fois pratiques pour se rafraîchir durant les périodes estivales chaudes et humides, les éventails étaient de véritables supports similaires à la photographie d’aujourd’hui permettant de faire voyager son porteur dans les provinces du Japon. Les maîtres de l’école picturale japonaise ukiyo-e ont utilisé les éventails comme support d’expression de leur créativité. D’abord vendus par des colporteurs ou dans des échoppes provisoires à l’occasion de fêtes, les éventails d’Edo ont commencé à être signés par des artistes célèbres et proposés à la devanture des marchands d’estampes et de livres illustrés à partir de la fin du 18ème siècle. Chacun avait son style : Hiroshige était plutôt un "documentaliste" souhaitant reproduire les plus beaux paysages du Japon, les scènes de vie, à la différence d’Hokusai, qui était de nature plus "créative" reconnu pour ses œuvres tirées de l’imaginaire japonais.\n\n#saintmaurdesfosses #paris #iledefrance #meditation #meditationparis #yoga #yogaparis #dzogchen #buddhism #bouddhisme #rigpa #nature #bienetre #zen #dharma #enlightenment #tibetanbuddhism

Caption:
4 juni 🙏 💫

För att uppnå något viktigt tillsammans måste var och en besluta sig för ta fullt ansvar och själv stå upp och agera. Samtidigt, istället för att vilja stå i rampljuset, är det viktigt att stödja andra som arbetar bakom scenen. Det är hemligheten bakom sann enhet. 

In order to achieve something great together, each person should resolve to take full responsibility and stand up to take action. At the same time, instead of seeking the limelight, it’s important to support others behind the scenes and to give your all. That’s the secret to true unity. 
From The New Human Revolution, Vol. 17, “Hope” chapter.

Caption:
BEYOND ACCEPTING OR REJECTING 

The open path is a matter of working purely with what is, of giving up altogether the fear that something may not work, that something may end in failure. One has to give up the paranoia that one might not fit into situations, that one might be rejected. One purely deals with life as it is.

Chögyam Trungpa "Cutting Through Spiritual Materialism" 

You do not have to abandon worldly activities in order to attain effortless unconcern. You should know that worldly activities and effortless unconcern are not two different things, but if you keep thinking about rejection and grasping, you make them two.

HuiNeng (the 6th Zen Patriarch), translation by Thomas Cleary, Classics of Buddhism and Zen, Volume 1 

The next time you lose heart and you can’t bear to experience what you’re feeling, you might recall this instruction: change the way you see it and lean in. Instead of blaming our discomfort on outer circumstances or on our own weakness, we can choose to stay present and awake to our experience, not rejecting it, not grasping it, not buying the stories that we relentlessly tell ourselves. This is priceless advice that addresses the true cause of suffering — yours, mine, and that of all living beings.

Pema Chödron, "Taking the Leap: Freeing Ourselves from Old Habits and Fears"

The Way is perfect like vast space
where nothing is lacking and nothing is in excess.
Indeed, it is due to our choosing to accept or reject
that we do not see the true nature of things.
Be serene in the oneness of things
and such erroneous views will disappear by themselves.

Sengcan (Third Zen Patriarch), Trans. Richard B. Clarke 

Since everything is but an apparition,
Perfect in being what it is,
Having nothing to do with good and bad,
Acceptance or rejection,
You might as well burst out laughing!

Longchenpa, Glimpse After Glimpse: Daily Reflections on Living and Dying"

Caption:
Dear Dharma Friends,
Thank you for your continued support and understanding of the dissemination effort of Soto Zen School.
This is 3rd time post regarding Noto peninsula in Ishikawa relief fund.
We extend our prays for the victims and their families and wish for their early recovery and restoration of life.
We appreciate it if you could kindly send checks to the Association of Soto Zen Buddhists so that we can transfer the amount to the Soto shu shumu-cho, Soto Zen Buddhism administrative headquarters office in Japan.
More than 100 Soto Zen temples affected by the disaster. We are sharing the photos of some temples.
We would appreciate it if you could help us raise relief funds with the support from your sangha and community members.
You can see more damages from this website. https://www.sotozen-net.jp/report/

・Payment deadline: June 30th, 2024
・Payment Method  1. Mailing cash or a check　2. PayPal mailto:info@sotozen.us
 *Check (payable to Association of Soto Zen Buddhists)
 Mailing Address: 123 South Hewitt St, Los Angeles, CA 90012

In Gassho,

Rev. Gengo Akiba, Director
Association of Soto Zen Buddhists a.k.a. Soto Zen Buddhism North America Office

Caption:
Las instituciones deben desmantelar los discursos hegemónicos que perpetúan la exclusión y el estigma. Esto implica una transformación radical de las políticas y prácticas educativas, legales y mediáticas. Las escuelas deben convertirse en espacios donde la diversidad no solo se tolere, sino que se celebre y se integre como parte fundamental del proceso educativo. Las leyes deben reflejar un compromiso inquebrantable con la igualdad y la justicia, asegurando que ningún individuo sea marginado o discriminado. Los medios de comunicación, por su parte, tienen la responsabilidad de representar de manera justa y digna a todas las identidades, desafiando los estereotipos y promoviendo narrativas inclusivas.

Caption: "Nonfabrication is a state of shamatha meditation that is free from any conceptual labeling. At this stage, there is no process of labeling our experience as one thing or another, such as thoughts of "resting" or "not resting" or "This is Mahamudra shamatha" or "This is not Mahamudra shamatha." We must be totally free from these fabrications. When we rest in that state of mind, there is a great sense of freedom."\n-Dzogchen Ponlop Rinpoche | June 7th | https://bit.ly/nsi24mmm

The Blue Temple, or Wat Rong Suea Ten, is a modern Buddhist temple in Chiang Rai, Thailand. Known for its striking blue and gold color scheme, it was designed by Putha Kabkaew, a student of the artist who created the White Temple. The temple's interior features intricate murals and a large white Buddha statue. Opened in 2016, the Blue Temple blends traditional Thai temple architecture with contemporary artistic elements.  #jeffreyrosenkrantz #postcard #postcardprint #thailand #chiangrai #watrongsueaten #bluetemple #buddhism #artexhibit #uniquearchitecture #travel #photos  https://travel.jeffreyrosenkrantz.com/photos/chiang-rai-blue-temple

Caption:
At a time when there is so much division, isolation and separateness, it’s more important than ever to enhance our emotional connection with others. 

We’re excited to announce that on Sunday 9th June David will be leading a Joyful Heart day retreat at Jamyang Buddhist Centre in London to explore the cultivation of the heart and mind through the practices of the Four Immeasurables. The teachings will be based upon Lama Alan’s book, Four Immeasurables: Practices to Open the Heart.

Explore the transformational practices of the Four Immeasurables - loving-kindness, compassion, empathetic joy and equanimity
Learn techniques that help you connect with others and overcome feelings of isolation.
Engage in meditations that open the heart and promote inner and outer harmony.
Learn how to increase understanding and empathy towards those who challenge us.
Share and learn with like-minded friends in group discussions.

Can’t join in person? You can access the teachings online as well! 
#tibetanbuddhism #buddhistretreat #buddhism #davidoromith #alanwallace #balanwallace #fourimmeasurables #ccn #lovingkindness #london #meditation #spirituality

Caption:
When the master makes a mistake, he realizes it. Having realized it, he admits it. Having admitted it, he corrects it. He doesn’t get offended by the ones who point out his faults. Instead, he treats them as his generous teachers. He catches himself when he’s not giving his best, and then he fixes it. He treats every faulty realization as an opportunity to increase self-awareness and become better, not an excuse to feel down.

(via fourminutebooksummary)

Caption:
***NEW SERIES OF CLASSES STARTS TUESDAY 4TH JUNE***
Starting this week Kadam Paul will teach a series of 4 classes - 'Four Truths to Change Your Life.' 
In this busy world our experiences of happiness are fleeting and short-lived, while inner peace often eludes us completely. Our negative states of mind, such as uncontrolled desire and anger, create endless problems for ourselves and others, and prevent us from fulfilling our deepest wishes. Buddha’s popular teaching on the Four Noble Truths offers a clear and simple solution, guiding us to an oasis of peace within our hearts. 
Everyone is welcome to join us for our meditation class on Tuesday evenings at Aberavon Leisure Centre. Suitable for beginners🙂
Fee: £20 for all four classes, or pay as you go £7 per class.  This class is included in all our membership levels.

Caption:
Buddhist Books: TIPIṬAKA 148
Mahāvagga II - Part 4
[00:35:21]  June 3rd, 2024

This is Part 148 of my recital of the "Tipiṭaka," the "Three Baskets" of pre-sectarian Buddhism, as translated into English from the original Pali Language.

In this episode, we'll continue reading "Mahāvagga II," from the "Vinaya Piṭaka," the first of the three "Piṭaka," or "Baskets." "Mahāvagga" literally means "Great Division."

Caption:
Meditation has been around for thousands of years. Early meditation was to help deepen understanding of the sacred and mystical forces of life. 

For some, meditation is most often used to relax and lower stress.

It is great that there is now scientific research into meditation to offer the physicalist explanations that so many modern minds want. 

But in a Buddhist context we can still have the spiritual aspects that allow for insight, connection and steer us away from delusion. 

There are many different reasons why people choose to learn meditation.  Many come to the centre initially for stress relief. 

But there’s more to it than that! 

During meditation, you focus on one thing. You get rid of the stream of thoughts that may be crowding your mind and causing stress. 

This process can lead to better physical and emotional well-being.

Caption:
"When all my earlier ways of grasping had faded away, I came to rest in the spontaneous vastness of the ever-pure ground of being. In that moment, everything that arose as the creative expressions of that ground dissolved naturally back into that same expanse.

This primordial ground- together with its creative expressions, free of modification, antidote, meditation practice, memory, grasping, and identification-is called path pristine awareness.

This ultimate reality is most easily seen in the absence of mental activity. As hopes, fears, negation, and affirmation dissolve into absolute space, their quiescence reveals the self-emergent primordial consciousness, the timeless mode of the great dharmakāya, free of all extremes, partiality, going, and coming.

Know that all appearances are the creative expressions of pristine awareness; they slip back into the essential nature, dissolving into the primordial womb like waves naturally subside back into the ocean..."

from "  Heart of the Great Perfection: Dudjom Lingpa's Visions of the Great Perfection, Vol. 1 " 
by B. Alan Wallace

Caption:
TOMORROW!! SPECIAL HOLIDAY: Celebrating Buddha's Turning the Wheel of Dharma Day 
🪷 Retreat: Offering Our Faith, Tues, June 4, 9am-4:30pm
🪷 Offering to the Spiritual Guide, 6:30pm

Every day we remember the extraordinary kindness of Venerable Geshe-la, our Root Guru and Founder of the New Kadampa Tradition. But on the auspicious day June 4 on Venerable Geshe-la’s birthday, at Kadampa centers around the world, with minds of rejoicing and gratitude, we offer him our faith through using the special prayer Request to the Holy Spiritual Guide Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso from his Faithful Disciples and collecting our Guru’s name mantra in a one-day retreat. Everyone is welcome to take part.

Schedule
Tuesday, June 4th
Session 1: 9am-10:30am
Session 2: 11:30am-1:00pm
Session 3: 3pm-4:30pm
6:30pm-7:15pm: Offering to the Spiritual Guide

🪷 Attend any/all sessions, please bring a vegetarian offering for the shrine. No registration necessary- donations accepted.

Caption:
Kiyomizudera temple in the wooded hills east of Kyoto famous for “jump off the stage at Kiyomizu” expression.

The expression “to jump off the stage at Kiyomizu” is the Japanese equivalent of the English expression “to take the plunge”. This refers to an Edo-period tradition that held that if one survived a 13-meter (43-foot) jump from the stage, one’s wish would be granted. During the Edo period, 234 jumps were recorded, and of the jumpers, 85.4 per cent survived. The practice was prohibited in 1872.

Caption:
The Ten Stages of Spiritual Cow-Herding
5: Herding the Cow

When a thought moves, another follows, and then another… There is thus awakened an endless train of thoughts. Through enlightenment all this turns into truth; but falsehood asserts itself when confusion prevails. Things oppress us not because of an objective world, but because of a self-deceiving mind. Do not get the nose-string loose; hold it tight, and allow yourself no indulgence

Never let yourself be separated from the whip and the tether,
Lest you should wander away into a world of defilement:
When she is properly tended, she will grow pure and docile,
Even without chain, nothing binding, she will by herself follow you.

Caption:
Early 2024 we met for the last Ensō for the time being. Ensō was an online sharing and practice circle led by people from the sangha ⭕️. It was a great experience to regularly, once a month host these sessions and to explore various forms of practices, like shaking, yoga asana, embodiment practices and guided meditations and so on. We want to thank the community for their help in the creation of a space for us all to share and experience new forms of practices.

Thank you to everyone who participated and also to the last remaining three of the original five founders: @annkn.aut @giacomosantiagorogado and @internalpractice pictured here in one of our organisational meetings. Thank you also to Claudia and Christina for their initial support and the dedication to create this community concept.

We might do another instalment of this at some point, maybe then in-person. Would you join?

Caption:
Sanghadana Lunch Offering and Patidana Transference of Merits from Jayathilake Family of California.

In Singalovada Sutta, Buddha taught: 
"In five ways, young householder, a child should minister to his parents as the East: 
(i) Having supported me I shall support them, 
(ii) I shall do their duties, 
(iii) I shall keep the family tradition, 
(iv) I shall make myself worthy of my inheritance, 
(v) furthermore I shall offer alms in honor of my departed relatives.

Caption:
Was wäre, wenn alle Taten sofort ihre Karma-Wirkung verursachen würden und nicht erst im nächsten Leben? Dieses Gedankenexperiment spielt der Autor auf sehr unterhaltsamen Weise in seinem Roman »Instant Karma« durch.

Ich bin mit relativ wenigen Erwartungen an das Buch herangegangen. Ich hatte sogar sogar befürchtet, dass es allzu belehrend werden könnte. Tatsächlich aber regt der Inhalt zwar zum Nachdenken an, kann jedoch gleichzeitig sehr gut unterhalten.

Das Cover ist zwar etwas nichtssagend, aber stimmungsvoll. Besonders die Farbgebung und der feste Einband können überzeugen. 

Das besondere an dem Buch ist, dass wir vielen verschiedenen Charakteren folgen. Diese werden gut dargestellt, sodass man sich schnell in sie hineinversetzen kann. Toll finde ich dabei auch, wie unterschiedlich die Personen sind und somit für fast jeden Leser Bezugspunkte bieten. 

Dabei werden die einzelnen Geschichten zu einer großen verwoben und hängen alle indirekt, teils auch direkt, miteinander zusammen. Dabei wird nie das Thema »Karma« aus dem Blick verloren. 

Der Schreibstil ist auf jeden Fall sehr angenehm. Die Szenerien werden zwar nicht unbedingt besonders bildlich beschrieben, aber dafür liegt der Fokus mehr auf der Geschichte. Die Kapitel sind meist kurz und dadurch sehr kurzweilig. Zudem eignet sich das Buch durch seinen Aufbau gut, um nur mal zwischendurch zu lesen.

Insgesamt hat das Buch auf jeden Fall einiges zu bieten. Mal bringt es einem zum Lachen, andermal regt es zum Nachdenken an. Insgesamt handelt es sich auf jeden Fall um eine Lektüre, die man zwar nebenbei lesen kann, aber dennoch auch länger auf sich wirken lassen sollte. Zudem eignet sich das Buch auch gut für Einsteiger und Interessierte an der Materie »Karma«, da die wichtigsten Elemente nicht nur theoretisch, sondern auch sehr praktisch erklärt werden.

Every day we remember the extraordinary kindness of Venerable Geshe-la, our Root Guru and Founder of the New Kadampa Tradition.
But on the auspicious day June 4 (Turning the Wheel of Dharma Day), at Kadampa centres around the world, with minds of rejoicing and gratitude, we offer him our faith through using the special prayer Request to the Holy Spiritual Guide Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso from his Faithful Disciples and collecting our Guru’s name mantra in a one-day retreat.

Caption:
The only true elegance is vulnerability.

Elegance means appreciating things as they are. 
There is a sense of delight and of fearlessness. 
You are not fearful of dark corners. 
If there are any dark, mysterious corners, 
black and confusing, 
you override them with your glory, 
your sense of beauty, 
your sense of cleanness, 
your feeling of being regal. 

Because you can override fearlfulness in this way, 
tantra, 
or the highest stage in Tibetan Buddhist practice, 
is known as the king of all the stages on the path. 
You take an attitude of 
having perfectly complete 
and very rich basic sanity.

—Chögyam Trungpa Rinpoche

Buddhist novices with their teachers on Lions Rock. Don't you just love these colourful bright orange, red and orange-yellow robes. It always lifts my heart when hearing them chant or watching them pray. 

Did you know the 3 mayor rules: 
👉 as a woman never sit next to a Buddhist Monk on the plane (I had to change seat) 
👉 you should not touch him or get too close to him 
👉 not take a photo of him (unasked which you shouldn't do with anyone) 

Here, they were supernice and open to tourists wanting to take pictures with them, so I did... ❤️

Caption:
Poetry happens, if you off route and uproot to listen.

I’m in #stokenham atm on a self-directed retreat with some glorious poetry friends. I earmarked this afternoon to walk and attempt o learn the lines for my commissioned poem for @devonwildlifetrust #ashdieback as were due to film imminently and I found this incredible place #fordchapel absolutely stuffed with beautiful #ashtrees . 

Before I left, over lunch @harulaladd told me that #buddhist monks often #meditate in graveyards to contemplate #death #transition and all that is #cycles #return #earth gosh 🙏 what a poetic connection of all things . 

Oh and this track by @hollyebonymusic !!!!!!! I can’t stop singing it x #savingdevonstreescapes @jazyatkinson #backlashforash @spork_poetry @exeter.library

Caption:
If you really wish to know me …
Then do not focus on other things
for a moment, and find that which
can not change within yourself. It is not found in ones clothes , name, opinions, beliefs, or identity that one has
chosen to play.
I am … ever here …
I am … the unchanging one …
reflecting your own unchangeable Self.

“There are 3 things I don’t envy”

One, I don’t envy magical power. Many people gave me leaf, stone, saying they went to India or Tibet, meditated on Buddha statue, suddenly got peace of mind and a leaf fell on their head. What am I supposed to do with that?

Second, I don’t envy people try to look for inspiration outside. You pay 8000 dollars to attend yoga or samadhi seminar, when come out, you’re the same person. We have all goodness of human being within. Why do we look for that outside? Some quotes give us tenderness in our mind. It’s because the author realized something in their mind, not from outside.

Third, as Buddhist practitioner, I don’t envy people practise riding on excitement. Many people practise or do retreat when excited. When not excited, everything is forgotten. What about continuity, stability, single minded? We focus so much on external, materialist things. This includes your devotion to teacher. You demand teacher should think, do what you like. And we extremely attach to the outer form of teacher, instead of looking at inner qualities.

To be born as human being, we have and should cherish our immeasurable inner qualities - pure goodness, genuineness. But when look within, we are frightened with so many emotions on surface, then tell ourselves "I don’t want to look any more. It’s too much." 

— Dilgo Khyentse Yangsi Rinpoche

Source 🙏 Lepus Oiostolus 🌷

Caption:
▫️▫️▫️
#สังขตลักษณะ 3
 
  ลักษณะแห่งสังขตธรรม คือ ธรรมที่ปัจจัยปรุงแต่งขึ้น ทั้งที่เป็นรูปธรรมและนามธรรม ทั้งที่เป็นโลกิยะและโลกุตตระ ทั้งที่มีชีวิตและไม่มีชีวิต ยกเว้นพระนิพพาน ซึ่งสังขตลักษณะนี้ จะทำให้เข้าใจสังขตธรรมได้ชัดเจนขึ้น ลักษณะแห่งสังขตธรรม มี 3 อย่าง คือ
— characteristics of the conditioned; condition; condition-marks of the conditioned

1️⃣ อุปฺปาโท ปญฺญายติ
 ความเกิดขึ้นปรากฏ คือ มีเหตุปัจจัยปรุงแต่งทำให้เกิดมีขึ้น เช่น ร่างกายเกิดจากธาตุ 4 ประชุมกันขึ้น วิญญาณ เกิดจากอายตนะภายในกับอายตนะภายนอกกระทบกัน เป็นต้น
 — Its arising is apparent.

2️⃣ วโย ปญฺญายติ
 ความดับสลายปรากฏ คือ เมื่อเกิดขึ้นมีขึ้นจากการปรุงแต่งของเหตุปัจจัยแล้ว ย่อมมีการแตกสลายไปในที่สุด
— Its passing away or subsidence is apparent.

3️⃣ ฐิตสฺส อญฺญถตฺตํ ปญฺญายติ
 เมื่อตั้งอยู่ ความผันแปรย่อมปรากฏ คือ เมื่อเกิดขึ้นมีขึ้นจากการปรุงแต่งของเหตุปัจจัยแล้ว ในระหว่างที่ยังดำรงอยู่ ยังไม่ถึงการแตกสลายไป ย่อมมีการแปรปรวนเปลี่ยนแปลงอยู่ตลอดเวลา

องฺ.ติก. 20/486/192.

 - ใจสั่งมา . คอม

Caption:
ONE WEEK FROM TODAY! 

Join us next Monday at 7:00pm for our special event with Kadam Morten: How Love Solves Your Problems.

Offered in person (for everyone) and online (for members only) 

Nurturing our innate potential for love – a mind of truly cherishing others – is the best thing we can do for ourself and for others. Buddha called the mind of love "the great protector" because it protects us from unhappiness and gives us the internal openness and flexibility to deal skillfully with all the various difficult situations we encounter.

Nurturing love in our heart heals our relationship with ourself, our family and friends, and, ultimately, our world. We may think this sounds idealistic but in truth it’s very practical. Buddha taught special methods whereby in meditation we learn to tune into our own capacity for love, to nurture it and expand it, opening it to more and more people (and animals!). In this series Kadam Morten will guide us in these heart enriching meditations and explain how we can apply them to solving the various problems in our lives.

Everyone welcome.

Learn more and register at: https://meditationinnewyork.org/how-love-solves-your-problems/

Caption:
Alright body! You got 5 days to get in gear and get well!! Next week is a busy week with two trips to NYC for the reading and a work event. 

This last week has been extremely difficult. I’ve been dealing with a serious gout attack. My foot has been in constant pain and has drained me badly, physically and mentally. The pain has been so intense I can’t meditate. I can’t swim, kicking my foot in water would be excruciating. Yesterday, I happened to have a full day outside and frankly, I overdid it. I came home early and started to feel feverish. I had chills throughout the night and today my disposition is just very weak. How I would love to be in bed all day but my boss is away on vacation and I have to keep the company going. Ugh…….

I need to find ways to strengthen my immune system and my energy levels. After the show in March I developed a fever. My last trip to NYC in April I came back and threw my back out. And now this bout stuck has really depleted me. This can’t continue. I would be appreciative of any advice people have for strengthening their internal health. (@tullyjohns any advice???)

Meanwhile, I’m just here. Surviving and working. That’s about it today. And yeah, I realize this Springsteen song isn’t about being sick, but it’s kinda close to what I’m feeling…

Caption:
［每天一品，淨化心靈］
⭐對於學佛人來說，愛面子就會有業障⭐

人為什麽會自大？要記住，自大的人都是為自己著想的，覺得自己很了不起；不自大的人，會把名譽地位看得很淡。想知道一個人是否自大、是否驕傲，你只要隨便把一個比他差的人放在他的前面，對地位差的人比對他好一點，你馬上就能看出這個人的驕傲本心了，他會馬上不開心。

師父在教育你們的時候，如果你覺得自己很了不起，師父就是不給你面子，就是要指出你的毛病，看你是否會臉紅，是否覺得自己丟了面子。學佛人有什麽面子啊？對於學佛人來說，愛面子就會有業障。

（已無所得，心無所得——摘錄盧台長講述於觀音堂）

Caption:
Kijk 👀 naar de voeten van Butsuzo.
Beelden van Boeddha's en bodhisattva's die in Japan voorkomen, zijn meestal blootsvoets.🦶
Het dragen van schoenen of laarzen wordt vaak gezien bij beelden van de hemelse goden (Deva godheid).

Look at the feet of Butsuzo.
The images of Tathagatas and Bodhisattvas in Japan are usually barefoot.
Wearing shoes or boots is often seen in the statues of the heavenly deities.

Caption:
问21：请问人的劣根性和无明习气有何联系和区别？

答：无明习气是指因为不明白才染成的习气，一般是指后天的，相对容易消除；劣根性是前世的遗传，是根性上的一些问题，要靠修心修行才能慢慢去除。

Caption:
Chiang Mai, Thailand 🇹🇭 Elephant Sanctuary 🐘🐘
•
The elephants in Thailand will always have a special place in my heart ♥️
•
Here’s a little back history-
•
Thailand is a majority Buddhist country and elephants are portrayed as sacred animals from their special symbolism in the practice of Buddhism. In Thailand elephants were very important in battle, with kings mounted on elephants fighting the Burmese to defend Thailand on many occasions. Before the modern era of war machines, elephants were heavily utilized by armies across Asia. Elephants in Thailand are protected by several laws and conservation efforts. The Asian elephants are an endangered species.  Between 3100 and 3600 can be found in 69 protected areas in Thailand. They can live up to 80 years. 
•

Caption:
For millennia, humanity has gazed at the stars and pondered the nature of reality. Different religions have offered profound and varied answers to this fundamental question. While their details may differ, a fascinating common thread emerges when we examine these diverse perspectives. 

Duality and Monism: Two Sides of the Coin

Many religions fall into two broad categories regarding reality: dualistic and monistic. Dualistic religions, like Zoroastrianism and some forms of Christianity, posit the existence of two fundamental realities - a material world and a spiritual world, often locked in opposition. Good versus evil, light versus darkness - these are expressions of this duality.

Monistic religions, such as Hinduism and Buddhism, propose a single, unified reality. Hinduism, with its concept of Brahman, the ultimate reality underlying all existence, emphasizes the interconnectedness of everything. Similarly, Buddhism views reality as a web of interdependent phenomena, arising and dissolving in a ceaseless flow.

Beyond Duality and Monism: The Journey Within

Some religions, like Judaism and Islam, transcend this binary. Judaism emphasizes a covenant relationship between God and humanity, grounding reality in a divine presence within creation. Islam, with its concept of tawhid (oneness of God), proposes a single, all-encompassing reality, with God as the ultimate source and sustainer.

The Shared Human Experience: A Common Thread

Despite these differences, a core theme connects these religions: the search for meaning and purpose within the vastness of existence. Most religions offer a path or practice to connect with what they consider the ultimate reality, be it through faith, devotion, or ethical living. This pursuit, a quest for transcendence, is a universal human experience.

Conclusion: A Tapestry of Belief

The nature of reality, as viewed by different religions, is like a rich tapestry woven with diverse threads. Duality and monism, the material and the spiritual, intertwine to create a profound sense of wonder and possibility. (Continued in pinned comments..)

#NatureOfReality #Religion #Philosophy #Spirituality #Duality #Monism #Hinduism #Buddhism
Hashtags: Religion, Philosophy, Monism, Duality, Hinduism, Buddhism, Spirituality, NatureOfReality

Caption:
The transfer of merit is  continuous and inexhaustible. 

"When a candle is lit in a dark room, it illuminates the room to some extent, but its power is limited. But if you use the same candle to light another candle, the total brightness increases. If you continue to do this, you can fill the room with brilliant illumination. The idea of transferring merit to others is like this." —Master Sheng Yen

Caption:
現場実習とボランティアとの違い

#参加する立場が変わると
#感覚も心の在り方も違う

臨床仏教師の現場実習は先月で終わりましたが、ひとさじの会が行っている上野の夜まわりに雨が降るなか赤いポンチョを着て参加しました。

日中は青空が広がり晴れ渡っていたのですが、天気予報どおり日が暮れて強い雨が降りだし、今宵は時どき雷も轟く夜まわりになりました。

今月末に約一時間の卓話を頼まれているので、臨床仏教について話をしたくて現場の様子を写真で紹介するためのボランティア参加でした。

前回までご一緒していた実習生も参加されていて、実習じゃなくなったら日誌から開放されたので、肩の力を抜いて参加できますねと声を掛けられて。

言われる通り実習生という立場ではないので、私も一人のボランティアとして参加してみると、目や耳や肌からの感じ方が今までと違う気がしました。

実習では自分の周りに目が向きがちだったのが、今回は俯瞰的に周りにも目を向けられていたようで、この感覚の違いに気づけたのは貴重な体験でしたね。

前回の最後の実習では「また次は２週間後に」と素直に言えなくてモヤモヤした気持ちがしていたのに、今夜は全く複雑な心境になることがありませんでした。

今回こそまた次いつ参加できるか分からないけど、お弁当や下着類やお薬などをお渡ししたあとに自然と「おやすみなさい」とお別れしてきました。

前回の夜まわりのあとブログを書いたときに、心の中に渦巻く感情を観察したつもりでしたが、まさか今回こんな風に感じたのは予想外でした。

時どき時間が許すときには夜まわりに参加してみて、次のときは自分がどんな風であるのかというのを経過観察して自分の移り変わりを感じてみたいですね。

Caption:
Here we are hanging with Sandra Oh post-performance of a powerful play she’s starring in, The Welkin. Sandra, how can you even stand up straight after putting out such huge emotional energy during more than two hours of high-intensity drama? 

If you are anywhere near New York, don’t miss this play! It is one of the best either of us have ever seen, so timely at this time in our country’s history. 

The plot: 
In rural England, 1759, as the country awaits the return of Halley’s comet, a young woman is sentenced to death. When she tries to escape the noose by claiming she is pregnant, twelve ordinary women are gathered to decide whether she is telling the truth.

Caption: Taking care of a Butsudan, or altar space is an important part of practicing Buddha-dharma. This space is where we make offerings, perform rituals, chant sutras, practice the six paramita, and connect with the ever present nature of awakening. The altar can be as elaborate or as simple as needed. Daily interaction is essential to the meaning of the altar as a place of practice. Just a small daily gesture of offering incense, tea, water, flowers, or fruit puts the intention of raising the bodhi mind with gratitude for the teaching. #butsudan#buddha#buddhism#zazen#mandala#yakushinyorai#medicinebuddha#bhaisajyaguru#shakyamuni#gautamabuddha#mantra#shingon#tendaishu#坐禅#仏教#仏壇#薬師如来#釈迦如来#真言#天台宗#佛#仏#法#dharma#マンダラ

Caption:
Wisst Ihr schon, wie Ihr bei den Europawahlen abstimmen wollt?

Vielleicht hilft es Euch ja bei Eurer Entscheidung, wenn Ihr die Positionen der Parteien zu Tibet kennt.

ICT hat im Vorfeld der Wahlen gemeinsam mit der Tibet Initiative Deutschland den Parteien insgesamt acht Fragen gestellt. Lest hier die Antworten von CDU/CSU, SPD, Bündnis 90/Die Grünen, FDP, Die Linke und Freien Wählern auf unsere Wahlprüfsteine: https://savetibet.de/tibet-wahlpruefsteine-2024/

Im Rahmen der EU-weiten Kampagne „EU 4 Tibet“ haben wir die zukünftigen EU-Abgeordneten zudem dazu aufgerufen, sich während ihrer Amtszeit für Tibet einzusetzen. Sie sollen sich dazu verpflichten, konkrete Maßnahmen zur Unterstützung des tibetischen Volkes fördern.

Mehr darüber findet Ihr hier: https://eu4tibet.org/country/germany/

(Foto: Mehr Demokratie-CC-BY-SA-3.0)

Caption:
I’ll discuss this in more detail in my next post, including the relevance/importance of learning to let the external world (including your accumulations) be an extension of the most free part of you (i.e. what does it mean to desire, build, and accumulate things in a way that is already free and imbued with the energy of letting go), as well as the importance of not bypassing patterns of “wanting” because you think you should be spiritual and want not.

This topic opens up a can of worms, so be patient and we’ll get into it in the next video.

For now, just let it impact you. And notice HOW it impacts you… 

Do you like and agree with it because it makes you feel comfortable with the pain of not having what you want? (that’s not the freedom or wisdom this post is inviting) 

Do you dislike and disagree with it because it triggers the egoic parts of you that want what they want and feel threatened by the idea of not getting it? (that’s worth paying to)

We’ll discuss in more detail, but feel free to share any thoughts below of what this brings up for you.

Karma Triyana Dharmachakra is a Tibetan Buddhist monastery in Woodstock, New York, which serves as the North American seat of the 17th Gyalwa Karmapa, head of the 900 year old Karma Kagyu Buddhist lineage. Caption:
Tatuagem com significado. Era o que a @le_krempel queria para sua segunda tattoo. 
.
Ela contou-me gostar do budismo e de seus ensinamentos e pediu para eu elaborar uma arte com um Buda e outros símbolos da religião a um desenho que ela já havia pensado. Também queria uma frase em latim.
.
Com essas informações em mãos eu elaborei duas artes para ela escolher. Além dos elementos que ela pediu, também coloquei alguns geométricos para criar um design único para a tatuagem.
.
Muito obrigado mais uma vez, Letícia, pela oportunidade e confiança.
.

Caption:
Part of the tour was to stop at the holy, high-altitude freshwater lake, Manasarovar @4500m's. It wasn't exactly around the corner, but a bum numbing 10+hr drive from Kyirong far into Western Tibet. 

It's a long journey, yes, but the stunning scenery makes up for it. The arid, vast, desert landscape captives, sky feels low (average altitude of Tibetan Plateau is +/- 4500m's), and the empty, ready-built villages add to the mysteriousness of this remote land. 

And then the colours. The traditional dresses and jewellery sparkle with a multitude of colours,  the sky is clear blue, and even our guesthouse walls delighted us with a combination of psychedelic shapes and colours.

Having heard and dreamed about Lake Manasarovar and Mt Kailas for years, it was a pretty special moment and feeling to actually see both for the first time, with your own eyes. Kailas was very awe-inspiring, and the tranquillity of Manasarovar was beautiful,  meditational even. We managed to spend a bit of time on its shores, deep on our thoughts soaking up the spiritual energy.

This was the centre of the world or universe for many believers, and you could see why. There was something magical and powerful about this place, having made thousands of pilgrims flock to its shores or to the base of the mountain for centuries. Despite different religions and beliefs, they all came united at this very same place on Earth.

With roomies @maja_pien_kos and Chris.

Caption:
Allen Ginsberg was born on this day in Newark New Jersey, 98 years ago! 

Born in this world
You got to suffer
Everything changes
You got no soul

Try to be gay
Ignorant happy
You get the blues
You eat jellyroll

There is one Way
You take the high road
In your big Wheel
8 steps you fly

Look at the View
Right to horizon
Talk to the sky
Act like you talk

Work like the sun
Shine in your heaven
See what you done
Come down & walk

Sit you sit down
Breathe when you breathe
Lie down    you lie down
Walk where you walk

Talk when you talk
Cry when you cry
Lie down    you lie down
Die when you die

Look when you look
Hear what you hear
Taste what you taste    here
Smell what you smell

Touch what you touch
Think what you think
Let go Let it go    Slow
Earth Heaven & Hell

Die when you die
Die when you die
Lie down    you lie down
Die when you die

New York, Subway, October 17, 1975

Gospel Noble Truths 
(The Four Noble Truths sung in a Blues form)
Mind Breaths: Poems 1972-1977, City Lights SF 1978
Photo: Steve Dickenson, with Allen’s camera, Seattle September 1, 1991

Caption:
Tonight we begin a new course: Experience Love Daily.
It is a prevailing notion that in order for us to be happy we must receive love from others. What if this conception is wrong? What if in order for us to be happy we must give love to others? In this way they naturally wish to give love to us. The point is, we must give in order to receive. If we only try to take the love of others our relationships will falter, remain unsatisfactory and inharmonious. Discover the truth of this supposition. 

Tonight's class: Recognizing the Kindness of Others
7:30 - 9 PM

EVERYONE WELCOME

Caption:
"Towards Buddhas and all beings, we should have equal reverence. In whichever sadhana, or practice, we perform, immediately after taking refuge, we generate the attitude of Bodhichitta, gaining the wisdom and compassion to be of benefit. From that moment on, other beings become the support for our practice. We may thus appreciate their great significance. For those who wish to attain enlightenment, the Buddhas and all other sentient beings have equal kindness."

- Kyabje Dilgo Khyentse Rinpoche

Practising Guan Yin Citta Dharma Door:
A Practical Buddhist Approach to Alleviating Suffering and Making Life Better🙏🏻 Effectively solving common issues relating to health, relationship, career and so on with the help of Guan Yin Bodhisattva❤️

现在人的烦恼多得数不胜数，苦不堪言，心灵已经累到极限，所以观世音菩萨才会应一个有求必应的法门。心灵法门传的是人间佛法，教导人们如何解决日常生活中的困难。心灵法门让大家通过“念经、许愿、放生”这三大法宝在人间消除业障，偿还业债，去除烦恼和病痛；通过 《白话佛法》指引人们修心修行，提高境界，最终脱离六 道轮回，走向西方极乐及四圣道。

Caption:
Upcoming online course
👆 CLICK PROGRAM CALENDAR IN THE BIO TO LEARN MORE

Join Dawn Haney and Nina Herzog for this weekly online program. By welcoming and gathering fat-identified people into community to explore the four noble truths of Buddhism, we hope to create new frameworks for understanding and practicing (fat) liberation. 

We will revisit basic Buddhist concepts – the three poisons of greed, hatred, and delusion; the three factors of existence of suffering, identity, and change; and the three refuges of Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha – dropping any interference from diet culture and drawing instead from kindness and compassion for our embodiment, as it is. In this new program, we will re-construct Buddhist practices of “embodiment” to make sense in our own fat bodies.

Caption:
.
.
.
青花の会
骨董祭 2024
.
.
.
No.3
Sin-me 
Nishi-mera 
15-16th century 
Ex Yufuin-Kuuso-no-mori Museum collection 

Sin-me was dedicated to shrines as a horse to be ridden by gods. As time went by, wooden carved horses were used instead of real horses, and eventually, board-shaped horses came into use, which became ema (votive tablets with horse paintings).
Although this work is decayed and missing its legs, it still looks divine and has not lost its spirit of carrying the gods on its back. Even if it is a fragment. Isn't that what “faith” is all about?
.
.
.
No.3
神馬
西米良
15～16c
由布院空想の森美術館

¥850,000円（税込)

神が騎乗する馬として神社に奉られていたが
時代が下がるとそれが実際の馬から木彫りになり
やがて板状のものになり絵馬が生まれた

朽ち果てその足はないが
いまだにその姿は神々しく
神を背負う気概を失っていない
たとえ欠片になってもだ
信仰とはそういったものではないだろうか

Caption:
為什麼要將本體觀想為自己的上師呢？ 這是因為雖然往昔有無數的佛陀出世為眾生宣講正法，但我們因為自己的業力深重，沒有得到解脫，現在上師重新來到我們面前，親自賜予我們傳承與灌頂，為我們開示阻塞惡趣道、開啟善趣道的妙法，引導我們趨入佛地，上師對我們的恩德很大，與我們的因緣更近。 

另外上師是一切功德之源，如果我們斷除狡詐之心，持之以恆虔誠地祈禱上師，今生便可獲得殊勝功德，所以應該將本體觀想為根本上師。

——希阿榮博堪布《次第花開》

Caption:
【今日法語】

共修

大圓滿祖師晉美林巴尊者曾經說：〝凡夫修持佛法如果沒有以三殊勝攝持，一旦出現心等違緣，功德很容易滅失與具德上師一起共修的話，功德不會滅失。〝凡夫修法時很難真正地以三殊勝來攝持，所以看到這樣的教言，我們應該很高興。

——希阿榮博堪布《寂靜之道》

Caption:
연꽃씨앗 염주에 대하여🪷
*
*
연꽃은 불교를 대표하는 상징적인 꽃이며, 매우 귀중하게 여겨지고 존경받는데, 이는 연꽃이 더러운 진흙 속애서 자라지만 더러움에 물들지 않고 자라나 아름답게 피어나여 청결하고 고귀한 특성을 가지고 있습니다. 연꽃 씨앗 또한 이러한 상징성을 담고 있으며, 영적 성장과 내적 평화를 나타냅니다.  연꽃 씨앗을 활용한 영적 수행은 내적 평화, 자기 인식, 우주에 대한 깊은 이해를 돕습니다. 또한 평화롭고 고요한 느낌을 전달합니다.

따라서 연꽃과 연꽃 씨앗은 불교에서 매우 중요한 상징적 의미를 지니고 있습니다. 이들은 정화, 깨달음, 영적 성장을 대표하는 존재들입니다.

또한 연꽃은 고요함과 평화로운 감정을 불러일으킵니다. 연꽃이 자신의 환경적 어려움을 극복하고 피어나는 능력은 불안에 시달리는 이들에게 위안과 영감의 원천이 될 수 있습니다. 연꽃 씨앗 염주는 부정적인 에너지를 정화하고, 집중력을 높이며, 웰빙의 감각을 키워주는것으로 알려져 있습니다.

하루 중 연꽃 씨앗 염주 또는 팔찌를 착용하는 것은 당신의 의도와 목표를 상기시켜줄 것입니다. 염주를 만지며 현재 순간에 집중하는 것은 불안한 생각을 멀리하고, 연꽃의 여정이 주는 힘과 희망을 느끼게 해줄 수 있습니다.
.
.
About the lotus seed Mala🪷
*
*
The lotus flower is a highly revered and symbolic flower in Buddhism, as it represents purity and enlightenment. Despite growing in muddy waters, the lotus flower blooms beautifully without being tainted, symbolizing the ability to rise above one‘s circumstances. The lotus seed also carries this symbolic meaning, representing spiritual growth and inner peace.

The spiritual practice of using lotus seeds can help cultivate inner peace, self-awareness, and a deeper understanding of the universe. They also convey a sense of tranquility and calmness.

Therefore, the lotus flower and lotus seeds hold immense symbolic significance in Buddhism, representing purification, enlightenment, and spiritual growth.

Moreover, the lotus flower promotes feelings of serenity and peace. Its ability to rise above the challenges of its environment can be a source of comfort and inspiration to those struggling with anxiety. Lotus seed beads are known to cleanse negative energy, enhance focus, and foster a sense of well-being.

Wearing your Lotus Seed mala or bracelet throughout the day serves as a reminder of your intentions and goals. Focusing on the present moment by touching the beads can help distract from anxious thoughts as well as provide a reminder of the lotus flower’s journey, offering a sense of strength and hope.

Caption:
"Vipassana: Unlocking the Mysteries of the Mind" by Vineet and Pratibha is a thoughtful and accessible guide to the ancient practice of Vipassana meditation. The authors, drawing from their personal journeys, demystify this profound technique with clarity and simplicity, making it a valuable resource for beginners. Their practical advice, step-by-step instructions, and relatable anecdotes set this book apart, offering readers an engaging and authentic introduction to mindfulness and self-awareness.

A significant focus of the book is the transformative power of the 10-day Vipassana retreat, which is essential for deepening meditation practice. These retreats involve complete silence and intense meditation, allowing participants to achieve a profound level of self-awareness and mental clarity. However, some readers might find certain sections of the book repetitive, as the authors reiterate key points to reinforce their importance. I have taken my own sweet time to grasp the content of the book as it is difficult to live with self and hence, this reading in itself was a different experience.

Overall, "Vipassana: Unlocking the Mysteries of the Mind" is a commendable introduction to Vipassana meditation. Despite minor issues with repetitive content, the book's clear explanations and practical guidance make it a worthwhile read. Vineet and Pratibha provide a comprehensive and inspiring look at a practice that has the potential to profoundly transform one’s life.

Caption:
🧘Join us for this month's Sunday Meditation on June 9 and 23, 2024, at Trisikkha Insight Meditation Center in Plant City, Florida, USA.

🌳The practice emphasizes developing mindfulness for inner strength, staying in the present moment, training the mind to be calm, awake, and wise, enabling it to remain undisturbed by emotions. It fosters mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom, empowering the mind to navigate daily life, detach from sensations, enhance self-esteem, let go of suffering, and access inner happiness. This leads to achieving freedom in the present moment.
😉Best of all, it's completely free!

📆Event Details:
 Date: June 9 and 23, 2024
 Time: 8:00 AM - 11:30 AM
 Location: 4207 US 92, Plant City, FL

⏰Schedule:
8:00 AM - Pay respect to the Triple Gem, Dhamma Talk by Ajarn Willie Pudsone
8:30 AM - 9:30 AM - Morning Chanting
9:30 AM - 10:30 AM - Walking Meditation
10:30 AM - 11:30 AM - Sitting Meditation
11:30 AM - Dedication of Merit, Communal Lunch 

🙋‍♀️To reserve your spot, reach out to us via comment, Facebook Messenger, text, or call at +18134732180. We're organizing seating and food arrangements for all attendees. Don't miss this opportunity to embark on a journey towards inner peace and fulfillment.

Caption:
In the Buddhist context, the sound of the gong is considered sacred.

It is used to mark the beginning and end of meditation sessions, to signal meal times in monasteries, and to call monks to prayer.

The deep, resonant sound of the gong creates an atmosphere of peace and introspection, helping practitioners to focus their minds and enter a state of deep meditation.

Caption:
Dengan demikian ia merenung tentang tubuhnya dengan melihatnya ke dalam, melihatnya dari luar dan melihatnya dari sudut kedua-duanya secara bergantian.

Atau ia berdiam dalam perenungan tentang apa yang dapat menimbulkan tubuh ini, atau … berdiam dalam perenungan tentang timbulnya dan lenyapnya kembali tubuh ini secara bergantian.

Dan ia berpikir: ‘Ini adalah sebuah tubuh’, dan perhatiannya itu diberikan hanya sampai pada tingkat menyadari, hanya sebagai pengenalan belaka; dan ia meneruskan perenungannya dengan tidak menggantungkan diri atau melekat kepada tubuhnya itu. Itulah yang harus dilakukan oleh seorang bhikkhu yang berdiam dalam perenungan dengan perhatian benar terhadap tubuhnya.

Sadhu Sadhu Sadhu🙏🏻🙏🏻🙏🏻

(MN.10)

We are pleased to share a news article from yesterday's Ceylon Today newspaper in Sri Lanka 🇱🇰, which highlights the significant work our teachers are conducting in Australia. True to our motto at 'Ministry of Nirvana', "Building a happier Australia 🇦🇺," we are committed towards spreading the Buddha’s teachings and enhancing mental well-being in the Australian and New Zealand 🇳🇿 communities. 🌿

The article details our services, which focuses on mindful awareness workshops to help manage stress, anxiety and depression emphasizing mental health as our priority. Our venerable monks who are well-versed in Buddhist philosophy, offer counseling sessions providing support and guidance to those in need.

If you know someone who needs help managing mental health challenges, please reach out to us and share this message with your loved ones and encourage them to participate in our programs.

Check the full article on page 14 here 👉🏼 https://ceylontoday.lk/wp-content/uploads/2024/05/CT-02-06-2024-CT.pdf

Caption: Although the writing is not verbatim mine, enough of the word choice is, and enough of the smaller phrases are. And those were taken from a typed file later compromised because my neighbors were selling my IP address, as was stated, or had some kind of involvement otherwise. This is what presaged the reminders of all of the commercials that were taken from private conversation. And the response seems to be kind of the norm for many people. It doesn't matter, for many, how someone might acquire the content they want to sell, so long as it isn't itself copyrighted. The common sense  of it is easy to ascertain. Caption:
The Avukana Buddha statue is a magnificent rock carving of a standing Buddha. This statue, which is a marvel of human creativity and artistry, is situated in the North Central Province of Sri Lanka, approximately 175 kilometres from Colombo at Avukana, close to Kekirawa. In the fifth century, under King Dhatusena's rule, Avukana was constructed.

Caption:

睦沢町にある東岳山妙楽寺。

シンプルな作りのお寺🌟
江戸時代中期の1725年に作られた本堂に入るととてもステキな欄間が出迎えてくれました✨
彫刻家、島村貞亮によるものだそうです。
なんと、波の伊八のお師匠さん！

天井には美しい龍と天女が。
狩野玉山によるもの。

御本尊の木造大日如来坐像は鎌倉時代のもの。
力強いお姿でした🌟

お寺の方たちもとても親切で嬉しかったです🌟
ありがとうございました✨

思いもがけず、ステキなお寺に参拝できました🌟

Caption: The Tiger Cave Temple l วัดถ้ำเสือ l is known for the tiger paw prints in the cave, tall Buddha statues and the strenuous flight of stairs to reach the summit. The temple is a Thai Buddhist meditation center and also has places of archaeological and historical significance. Examples of these historical attractions are stone tools, pottery shards, and molded Buddha footprints. At the top of the mountain there is a large golden Buddha statue. This statue, other temple buildings, and much of Krabi town can be seen from shrine at the top of the stairs.\n\n#thaisacredart #thai #thailand #thai #bangkok #buddha #buddhism #temple #menfashion #menwithstyle #muaythai #thaiboxing #tattoo #泰国 #kingpower #talisman #goodluck #rich #contemporaryart

Caption:
做一名教育家應本著可以做到、能做到、該做到的，盡心去做，做不到的事不必強求；盡心盡力呼籲大家認同，可是當他人不認同時亦應無所怨尤。宗教師亦是如此。

釋迦牟尼佛成佛後廣度眾生，地藏菩薩說「地獄不空，誓不成佛」。但眾生那麼多，眾生的煩惱也似乎愈來愈多，可是身為宗教家是永遠不會失望的，只會永無休止地盡其在我。教育學生也應如此，事先要有面對艱難的心，本著理念和理想，能奉獻多少就奉獻多少，能救幾人便救幾人。

有人認為，不乖的小孩由我摸摸頭，祝福一下就能改善。若真的有用，我又何必如此忙碌到處弘法，奔波勞累？只要坐著專門摸頭即可。也有人問說：「社會風氣不是很好，是否可由高階層的政治領袖們帶頭改良風氣？」我說：「是的，所謂『上行下效』是有可能的，但也不是絕對有用。」因為有許多事，不是少數高階層人士所能夠解決的。

佛法說「共業」，即是要結合大家共同的力量，希望社會大眾養成共識，但是共識的養成也不能一廂情願，不見得人人都會來響應。也有人說，大家來信佛就會國泰民安、世界和平，事實並非如此單純。畢竟人類的問題，並非完全是客觀的，尚有個人主觀的因素存在。因此，用教育的確可以達到某種程度的改變，但是要想完全達到理想的教育目的則是奢求。所以，能救多少算多少，反而是更積極務實的作法。

文/聖嚴法師  圖/Jean Li

Caption:
Join us in the Prayer Room as Khenpo Karze offers a Dharma banquet of teachings and a monthly Q&A at KPC.

Khenpo Karze teaches at 7:30pm on the 1st and 3rd Wednesdays, with a Q&A on the 4th Wednesday of every month. 

Knowledgeable, cheerful, open and delighted to engage with westerners, Khenpo Karze offers his wisdom from years of study at Namdroling in India. 

If you can't attend in person, join us on Zoom (link provided at registration). Register for a monthly class subscription or one class at a time. Link in bio.

Please be sure to select “Make this a monthly donation” when signing up for the monthly subscription.

Caption:
Храм на берегу Восточного моря. 

Храм Наксанса была основана в 671 году на территории Корейского государства Силла. По легенде Бодхисаттва Авалокитешвара сам указал построить здесь храм, явившись монаху во время медитации. 

Наксанса неоднократно подвергался уничтожению: войны, монгольское нашествие и страшнейший лесной пожар 2005 года. Поэтому многие строения перестриивались и восстанавливались. 

Сейчас здесь находится несколько национальных сокровищ, а также самая большая статуя Бодхисаттвы Авалокитешвары в Азии.

🪷 Naksansa temple (낙산사), Yangyang (양양군). 

P.S. Фотография внутри храма была сделана с разрешения сотрудника.

Karena kita datang ke duniawi, kita tidak membawa  apa apa, ketika mati juga tidak bisa membawa apa apa, kita tidak ingin serakah terhadap segala sesuatu di dunia ini, menggunakan hati yang baik hidup didunia ini dengan baik,  Dalam masyarakat saat ini, 
Masih belum ada penyakit, tidak ada bencana alam atau bencana akibat ulah manusia. Ini sudah merupakan berkah. 
Kita harus berpuas hati dan bahagia.

Caption:
**ថ្ងៃនេះជាថ្ងៃថ្វាយព្រះភ្លើងព្រះបរមសព សម្តេច ព្រះសង្ឃ មហាសង្ឃរាជ ទេព វង្ស យាងថ្វាយដោយព្រះករុណា ព្រះបាទសម្តេចព្រះបរមនាថ នរោត្តម សីហមុនី ព្រះមហាក្សត្រកម្ពុជា និងមានការចូលរួមពីសម្តេចនាយករដ្ឋមន្រ្តី និងមន្រ្តីគ្រប់លំដាប់ថ្នាក់

រដ្ឋាភិបាលកំណត់ថ្ងៃនេះ ជាថ្ងៃកាន់ទុក្ខ ហើយរដ្ឋបាលរាជធានីភ្នំពេញ បានប្រកាសថា គ្រប់ស្ថានីយទូទស្សន៍ និងវិទ្យុទាំងអស់ ត្រូវផ្អាកសកម្មភាពសម្តែង និងការចាក់ផ្សាយទស្សនីយភាពទាំងឡាយណា ដែលមានលក្ខណៈគគ្រឹកគគ្រេង នៅថ្ងៃទី ០៣ ខែមិថុនា ឆ្នាំ២០២៤។

សូមរម្លឹកថា សម្តេចព្រះមហាសង្ឃរាជ ទេព វង្ស បានសុគត កាលពីថ្ងៃទី ២៦ ខែកុម្ភៈ ឆ្នាំ ២០២៤ ក្នុងព្រះជន្ម ៩៣ ព្រះវស្សា ដោយជរាពាធ ដោយព្រះសពរបស់សម្តេច។ #ថ្វាយព្រះភ្លើង #ស្តេចសង្ឃ #tepvong #event #buddhism

Caption:
🕌✨ In a temple, worshippers seek the Buddha's gaze; in a museum, the Buddha is the object of the visitor's gaze. This paradox highlights the 'musealization' of living traditions.

🔍 For insights into musealization, heritage, and society, join INSTUCEN TRUST's  Allan Oscar Ritchie and Raamesh Gowri Raghavan for an exploration!!

🗺️ Part 1: Walk through the evolution of Buddhism and major sculptural schools, interacting with artefacts.
💬 Part 2: Discuss the museum's role (as a colonialist-nationalist construct) in relation to living religions like Buddhism and Jainism, and the paradoxes in heritage conservation.

📅 Date: 9th June 2024
⏰ Time:  2 p.m. to 5 p.m. I.S.T
💰. Fees : Rs. 800/-
📍 Location: CSMVS Buddhist and Tibetan Galleries
 
For more information, please click the link in our bio 🔗

Caption:
Ladakh is a union territory of India but it feels like a world of it's own. It is known for it's rich cultural heritage, Tibetan Buddhist monasteries, and breathtaking landscapes.

The capital of the region - Leh - is situated at an altitude of roughly 3500m above sea-level, giving it a cold desert climate. It is nestled in the Indus River valley and surrounded by the stunning and peaceful Himalayan mountains 🗻

After months of heat and humidity, I welcomed the cold weather 🤭 Being from England, it felt like a taste of home to wrap up in layers, and this wooly headband was perfect on days I wanted to tie my dreadlocks up!

Caption:
bhimarmychief कल मध्य प्रदेश के जिले सागर के बरोदिया नेनागिर में पहुंचकर पीड़ित परिवार से मुलाकात कर दुख बांटा एवं तीनों मृतकों को विनम्र आदरांजलि अर्पित की।

Caption:
We speak of wisdom and concentration as separate things, but in essence they are one and the same. They arise from the same place but take different directions. It’s like a mango. A mango is first small and green. It then grows larger and larger until it is ripe. The small mango, the large one and the ripe one are the same mango, not different mangoes. Only its conditions have changed. In Dhamma practice, one condition is called concentration, and the later condition is called wisdom, but in 
actuality samadhi and panna are both the same thing, just like the mango.
(Ajahn Chah)

Caption:
“People may have been good to you, but it’s not the case that they always will be. The human mind is very changeable, and they could change without notice. You can’t rely on their goodness as your nourishment. You’ve got to learn how to take as your nourishment whatever goodness you can give rise to in yourself.

This is where goodwill [mettā] is very important. If, when you’re not wishing any harm on anybody, harm does come to you, you’re not going to feel guilty or that somehow it was a punishment for your unskillful attitude. You can just chalk it up to past kamma and leave it at that. It’s a much cleaner and more bearable way of thinking.”

~ Thanissaro Bhikkhu “Unsentimental Goodwill”

Caption:
Super Cub × Seogwangsa

The intial building of Seogwang Temple in Wimi was erected in 1961, after Seunim Sugyeong [𝘴𝘦𝘶𝘯𝘪𝘮 is a title for a Buddhist monk] prepared the land and built a thatched-roof building with donations from Bodhisattva Go Myeong-sim (Gong Deok-hwa), the founder of what was then, it seems, a smaller temple in a private residence. At the time, Seunim Sugyeong had finished his studies under him and hoped to build a proper temple. The temple’s founder and about 500 believers, a large number at the time, supported his wishes, and Seunim Sugyeong became the temple’s first 𝘫𝘶𝘫𝘪, or abbot. The temple was then rebuilt in 1987 into the current 40-pyeong (approx. 130 sqm) main hall.

In 1995, the Seogwangsa Choir was formed when Seunim Seonggeun took office as the temple’s second juji. Five years later, he established the Buddhist Social Welfare Center in a 50-pyeong (approx. 150 sqm) two-story building on the east side of Doryang, creating a choir practice room as well as Gwaneumjeon, a shrine for Avalokiteśvara, a tenth-level bodhisattva associated with great compassion.

Source: 제주불교신문 [Jeju Buddhist Newspaper]; please note that the text may include some inaccuracies.

Caption: 6月2日下午1点，贤翱法师带动念佛课程。法师首先带领大家做念佛拍手操，这种简易的运动帮助大家放松身心，调节气息。接着，法师带领大家进行户外经行念佛。此时阳光明媚，居士们在和煦的阳光下，跟随法师的步伐，缓缓前行，身心保持正念，专注当下，默念佛号。大家在这种宁静的氛围中，感受到了内心的安详与喜悦。\n#voiceofgreatcompassion#voice#meditation#walking#longquangreatcompassionmonastery#buddhism#utrecht
Hashtags: meditation, utrecht, walking, voiceofgreatcompassion, voice, longquangreatcompassionmonaste, buddhism

Caption:

大好きな人生の先輩のお一人です😍

Caption:
Karma Chagme Rinpoche said that although all sentient beings had, at one time or another, been his mother, as they have no memory of that relationship, they feel free either to attack him or remain strangers. We, on the other hand, know of our connection; how, then, can we not be friendly with everyone?

- Dzongsar Khyentse Rinpoche 

Source 🙏 Vang Vọng Lời Phật Dạy 🌷

Caption:
Het is de week van de mentale gezondheid 💚

Vrijdag 7 juni geef ik twee lessen: de eerste bij @obamsterdam Javaplein. Deze is speciaal gericht op het effect van Japanse yoga op je mentale en emotionele gezondheid. Stuur mij een mailtje of berichtje als je mee wil doen: 
info@mariskagunsing.com
Neem je eigen matje mee. 
Deelname is gratis.

De tweede les is bij @samana_yoga_center, gericht op hoe je in de komende drukte van de zomer balans blijft vinden tussen activiteit en ontspanning. 
Stuur mij een mailtje of berichtje als je mee wil doen. Matjes zijn aanwezig en deelname is op donatie basis.

Tot op de mat! 🧘‍♀️

.

Caption:
In every disappointment there is an opportunity to wake up: disappointments reveal our attachment to expectations. 

Being human requires us to look ahead and imagine the future, so expectations are not inherently bad. It is when we get attached to our expectations - when we refuse to adjust them, that we get into trouble. 

Any time you feel disappointed is a good opportunity to observe yourself. The length of time that the disappointment persists, reveals the extent to which you’ve become attached to your expectations. 

Expectations - our amazing, uniquely human skill to imagine the future - should serve us, not make life harder on us. 

So whenever you find yourself to be disappointed, ask yourself what (implicit) expectations were violated. These expectations are of your own making. They only exist in your mind. 

Disappointments, in this sense, wake us up to reality. Try looking at disappointments with curiosity. Where have you accidentally gotten attached to an illusion of your own making?

Caption: 천수관음 블랙앤그레이

🧘 Personal Practice Retreat – Days 2 & 3 re-cap

Prof Paul Gilbert, Choden and our delegates were joined by Dr William Van Gordon for Days 2 & 3 of our Personal Practice Retreat at Colwick Hall in Nottingham (UK) & Online last week.

William was a Buddhist Monk for 10 years and is now a Chartered Psychologist and Associate Professor of Contemplative Psychology at the University of Derby.

☸️ Delegates continued their experiential journey with a series of practices which aimed to develop understanding of ultimate bodhicitta and its two main components: awareness and emptiness. 

Following a series of morning practices and a silent mindful lunch, delegates explored the Buddhist wisdom principle of emptiness, used to address the tendency that individuals often see and interact with the world in a highly self-orientated and ego-driven manner.

Finally, Day 3 focused on Integration and explored how both biological and transcendental approaches can work together and inform our practice and teaching of compassion, including the use of mantras and visualisations to help cultivate our compassionate self and mind.

The feedback received so far has been very positive and we have really enjoyed spending the 3 days with everyone both in-person and virtually.

🙏Thank you so much to everyone who joined us.

If you would like to be notified of similar events, sign up for our free newsletter via our website to join our mailing list https://i.mtr.cool/epurokaloz

Caption: Dalit Panther Foundation Day.\nThe Dalit Panthers is a social organisation that seeks to combat caste discrimination. It was led by a group of Mahar writers and poets, including Raja Dhale, Namdeo Dhasal, and J. V. Pawar in some time between the second and the third semester of 1972.It was founded as a response to the growing discontent among the Dalit youth during the 25th Independence Day celebrations. Inspired by the Black Panther movement in the United States, poet-writers J V Pawar and Namdeo Dhasal founded the Dalit Panthers, urging a boycott of the Independence Day revelry, terming it a ‘Black Independence Day’. The movement’s heyday lasted from the 1970s through the 1980s, and it was later joined by many Dalit-Buddhist activists.\n#dalitpanther #jaybhim #buddhism
Hashtags: dalitpanther, jaybhim, buddhism

Caption: In a sense everything is dreamlike and illusory, but even so, humorously you go on doing things. For example, if you are walking, without unnecessary solemnity or self-consciousness, lightheartedly walk toward the open space of truth. When you sit, be the stronghold of truth. As you eat, feed your negativities and illusions into the belly of emptiness, dissolving them into all-pervading space. And when you go to the toilet, consider all your obscurations and blockages are being cleansed and washed away. #DudjomRinpoche #LamaSuryaDas #Dzogchen #Meditation  #Mindfulness #SelfInquiry #NonDual  #Buddhism #Healing #Wellness #Yoga  #Dharma #AwakeningtheBuddhaWithin #Awareness #HowtoHeal

Caption:
शीलाशिवाय शिक्षणाची किंमत केवळ शून्य

“आपण धर्मासाठी सत्याग्रह केला. धर्मांतराचा ठराव केला. सर्वकाही केले. आता आपण आपले मन पवित्र केले पाहिजे. आपला सद्गुणांकडे ओढा असला पाहिजे. अशारितीने आपण धार्मिक बनावयास पाहिजे. आपण शिकलो म्हणजे सर्वकाही झाले असे नाही. शिक्षणाचे महत्त्व आहे यात शंका नाही. मात्र शिक्षणाबरोबरच माणसाचे शीलही सुधारले पाहिजे. शीलाशिवाय शिक्षणाची किंमत केवळ शून्य आहे. ज्ञान हे तलवारीसारखे आहे. समजा एखाद्या माणसाच्या हाती तलवार आहे. तिचा सदुपयोग की दुरूपयोग करावयाचा हे त्या माणसाच्या शीलावर अवलंबून राहील. तो त्या तलवारीने एखाद्याचा खूनही करील किंवा एखाद्याचा बचावही करील. ज्ञानाचेही तसेच आहे. एखादा शिकलेला माणूस त्याचे शील चांगले असेल तर आपल्या ज्ञानाचा उपयोग लोकांच्या कल्याणासाठी करील परंतु त्याचे शील चांगले नसेल तर तो आपल्या ज्ञानाचा उपयोग लोकांचे अकल्याण करण्याकडेही खर्च करील. शील हे धर्माचे मोठे अंग आहे. शिकलेली माणसे नुसती पोटभरू असून भागणार नाही. ज्यांना स्वार्थापलिकडे काही दिसत नाही; ज्यांना थोडाही परार्थ करता येत नाही ती माणसे नुसती शिकली म्हणून काय झाले? त्यांचा दुसऱ्याला उपयोग तो काय? ’तव्याचा जाय बुरसा, मग तो सहजच होय आरसा.’ शिक्षणाचा उपयोग असा झाला पाहिजे.”

डॅा. बाबासाहेब आंबेडकर, रावली कॅम्प, सीॲान, मुंबई, ३ जून १९५३

संदर्भ 
• डॅा. बाबासाहेब आंबेडकर लेखन आणि भाषणे खंड १८, भाग ३, पृष्ठ क्रंमाक ३६०

Caption:
The Kalachakra is a stunning visual representation of the cosmic wheel of time. In its intricate details, it conveys the the concept of how the universal cycles of the planets are one and the same with the cyclical processes of human life - breathing, sleep, birth, death...

To meditate on the Kalachakra is a deep reflection of the temporary nature of all reality. "This too, shall pass."

Caption:
🌞
Annyira szokásunkká vált a kifelé tekintés, hogy szinte teljesen elveszítettük a belső lényünkhöz vezető utat
Megrettenünk attól, hogy magunkba pillantsunk, mivel kultúránk nem adott semmiféle képet arról, hogy mit fogunk ott találni
Esetleg még az is eszünkbe juthat, hogy ha megtesszük, akkor beleőrülünk
Az egónak ez az egyik legutolsó, leghatékonyabb trükkje, amellyel megpróbálja megakadályozni, hogy felfedezzük igaz természetünket
Ezért tesszük annyira zsúfolttá életünket, hogy még a legkisebb kockázatát is elkerüljük annak, hogy magunkba kelljen pillantanunk
Már a meditáció gondolata is elriasztja az embereket
Amikor meghallják azokat a szavakat, hogy én-nélküliség vagy üresség, azt gondolják, hogy ezeknek a dolgoknak a megtapasztalása olyan lehet, mintha valakit kilöknek az ürhajó ajtaján, ahol aztán örökre a sötét, fagyos űrben lebeghet
Semmi sem lehetne távolabb az igazságtól
Ebben az állandó zajlásnak szentelt világban a csönd és nyugalom megriasztja az embert, ricsajjal és lázas tevékenykedéssel védekezünk ellene
A tudatunkba való bepillantás a legutolsó dolog, amit meg mernénk tenni
- Szögjal Rinpocse -
#buddhism#buddhismus

Caption:
नमो बुद्धाय
—🌷🌷🌷—

हम ज्ञान और एकाग्रता को अलग-अलग चीजें कहते हैं, लेकिन मूल रूप से वे एक ही हैं। वे एक ही जगह से उत्पन्न होते हैं, लेकिन अलग-अलग दिशाएँ लेते हैं। यह आम की तरह है। एक आम पहले छोटा और हरा होता है। फिर यह बड़ा होता जाता है और पकने तक बड़ा होता जाता है। छोटा आम, बड़ा आम और पका हुआ आम एक ही आम हैं, अलग-अलग आम नहीं। केवल उनकी स्थितियाँ बदल गई हैं। धम्म अभ्यास में, एक स्थिति को एकाग्रता कहा जाता है, और बाद की स्थिति को ज्ञान कहा जाता है, लेकिन वास्तव में समाधि और पन्ना दोनों एक ही चीज़ हैं, बिल्कुल आम की तरह।

—🌷🌷🌷—

#buddhism

Caption:
The evolution of Waterloo House and its entwined connection with UK dance music. 

The Assembly Rooms, Leeds, behind the Corn Exchange, first opened in 1777, was always place of joy and community (and dancing!). In the 90s it was home to BackToBasics’ “Rehab”. So-called as a 2 finger response to the media of the time referring to UK rave-goers as “The chemical generation”. And now it continues not just as a place of love and community, but as a light in a darkening world where people can learn that there’s a different way through this life. Revealing how peace can be found no matter how difficult things get. 

1. BackToBasics’ “Rehab”. 
2. The same view now! Meditation room.
3. Evening of view of the Assembly Rooms / Waterloo House as it is now @meditationinleeds 
4. Founder and CEO of BackToBasics @davebeero and Resident Teacher @gendornying @meditationinleeds 
5. Coming together. Gen Dornying and Dave Beer and 1000s of seekers at @soakevents and @fac51thehaciendaofficial amazing event in leeds in May 
6. On the stage with @wearekklass 
7. @davebeero , @rowetta and @gendornying 
8. @gendornying teaching on happiness at @meditationinleeds

Caption:
ทว่า "เจดีย์ทรงปรางค์" ที่เจ้าสามพระยาสร้างไว้ที่วัดราชบูรณะ ได้รับอิทธิพลจากปราสาทในเขมร ซึ่งหากย้อนเวลาไปในสมัยพุทธกาลตามลำดับ จากสาญจิเจดีย์ (Sanchi) จนถึงสมัยอยุธยา จะเห็นได้ว่าเจดีย์มีการพัฒนารูปทรงไปตามวัฒนธรรมตามยุคสมัย 

โดยรวมรูปทรงของพุทธเจดีย์ที่ได้รับการพัฒนาไปไม่มาก นอกจากในพื้นที่เอเชียตะวันออกเฉียงใต้ (โดยเฉพาะ ในประเทศพม่า ไทย กัมพูชา/เขมร) ที่ดูเหมือนว่าจะมีรูปร่างเฉพาะตามพื้นที่ ทั้งที่เป็นรูปทรงปราสาท ทรงดอกบัว และที่เรียกว่า “ปรางค์” 

#วัดราชบูรณะอยุธยา #อยุธยา #เจดีย์ #เจดีย์ศึกษา #ประวัติศาสตร์ #โบราณสถาน #พุทธศาสนา #พุทธปรัชญา #Thailand #Watratchaburana #Ayuttaya #buddhism #ayuttayathailand #history #travel #worldheritage #stupa #stupastudy #zineth_line #sanchi

Caption:
"Now until the dualistic identity mind 

melts and dissolves, 

it may seem that we are parting. 

Please be happy. 

When you understand the dualistic mind, 

there will be no separation from me. 

May my good wishes fill the sky." 

~ Yeshe Tsogyal

Source 🙏 Erik Jensen 🌷

That's why they say in dzogchen nothing is forbidden, but it is up to you to decide who you are as you engage in any activity. Of course other people are deceiving you. Other people are trying to hook you into being this familiar form. Because if you are you they think you are then that is confirming who they think they are...breaking free is very difficult when there are lots if people who want to keep you in the addictive, mutually confirming cycle of samsara. That is why dharma is saying if you want to practice dharma go to a place where no one know your name. Because nobody will be able to out their projections onto you...As we know attachment is very sticky and the ego is very wobbly and anxious. It wants confirmation. It wants reassurance. So you can spend alot of time in mutual grooming, in combing each other, taking the lice out, saying your lovely, you are wonderful, you are really nice and then you die. So it is not about abandoning the world or rejecting the world. It is not about renunciation it is always about the question don't blame the object, don't blame the other people. Other people are entitled to be however they are. They can be friendly or annoying of whatever they are. That's just how they are. My focus is who am I

- James Low

Caption: The rays of blessing light of the Buddha of Infinite Light touched a lotus in the Milk Ocean in the Southwest direction from Bodhgaya. That was twelve years after the Maha Parinirvana of the Buddha. As a result, Guru Rinpoche was born miraculously in that lotus. He had a “lotus birth" without human parents. This is why he is called Padmasambhava, the Lotus Born.Guru Padmasambhava was known in Tibet as one of the founding fathers of Tibetan Buddhism, who appeared in Tibet in 749 A.D, and spent 54 years.His love is unconditional, whether you are a good person or bad. He has boundless power to fulfill your needs, if you are mentally and karmically open.\n\n. #thangka #art #tibetan #fyp #foryou #peace #buddhism #buddha #boudha #history #handmade #painting #gold #natural #artschool #handcrafted

Caption:
Goreicha, the Tea of the Spirits at Ichibata Yakushi Temple 🍵

Since ancient times, tea has been considered to be a medicine to cure many diseases in Japan. Tea was introduced to Japan from China at the same time as Buddhism. Tea was said to be an elixir that could improve the drinker’s health and grant them a long life. Ichibata tea also has a long history and the name “Ichibata” comes from “Ichi no Bata” which could be translated as “the first medicine garden” of the Buddha of medicine and healing, Buddha Yakushi Nyorai.

Goreicha means “tea of the spirits” and it is a special tea harvested in Ichibata in Izumo. Ichibata’s Goreicha tea leaves are first used as an offering to Buddha Yakushi Nyorai during prayer and are shared with worshippers afterwards. If you buy a pack of tea to drink at home, it should be brewed in boiling water for 5 to 10 minutes to enjoy its full taste and aroma.

You can also taste the Ochatō, the “tea of the faith” when visiting the temple. Ochatō is Goreicha when brewed in the “water of the spirits”. This water comes from the well located in the temple's sacred grounds and thus from the mountain where the temple is located. In the temple grounds, there is a dedicated place with a sign reading “お茶湯” (Ochatō) where you can buy an original Ichibata Yakushi temple bottle (500￥/ around 3.50€) and fill it with Ochatō. It is said that it is good for the body and the eyes, so don’t hesitate to enjoy it if you come to visit the temple.
